730684f.title: Bridges - Brooklyn Bridge - [Entrance to Brooklyn Bridge in 1857.]
730684f.text:
"Entrance to the Brooklyn Bridge in 1857" p.227

Pelletreau, William S.
Early New York houses with historical-genealogical notes. New York; Francis P. Harper, 1900.

730663f-a.title: Bridges - Brooklyn Bridge.
730663f-a.text:
(2)
A general view westward from the Brooklyn Bridge (under construction), over the Cherry Hill section, Printing House Square, City Hall Commons and westward to the Hudson (North) River. Shown in the foreground, is the Manhattan abutment of the bridge, with the Roosevelt Street Ferry to Broadway, Brooklyn adjoining. Points of interest shown are, U.S. Post Office,
Tribune Building, Harper's and the Newsboy's Home.
About 1870-1875.
Brown Brothers.
Published in the American on December 1906, and the New York Times
of October 20, 1912.

Neg. # 1756

730664f-a.title: Bridges - Brooklyn Bridge.
730664f-a.text:
A general view westward from the incompleted Brooklyn Bridge. In the background is the North (Hudson) River and its far Jersey shore. Silhouetted against same are the Post Office and the
Tribune building.
1876
American Studio
Gift of Urbrock Collection

Neg. # 4292

730665f-a.title: Bridges - Brooklyn Bridge.
730665f-a.text:
The Brooklyn Bridge under construction, with the "Catwalk" and Manhattan anchorage in the foreground. Also shown is a general view westward over the City Hall and Printing House Square area, to the Hudson River, with its Jersey shore line just beyond. Note how the U.S. Post Office and the Tribune Buildings predominated at this date.
About 1878-1879.
Ewing Galloway.

Neg. # 2285

730667f-b.title: Bridges - Brooklyn Bridge - [View of the bridge, while under construction.]
730667f-b.text:
The Brooklyn Bridge under construction and showing the stone supports and cable, prior to the laying of the cat walk. This view is northeastward from Manhattan and shows the Brooklyn shore in the background. Note the masted schooners in the foreground on the South Street waterfront.
About 1880.
Gift of H.D. Jewett.

NEG. #4402

Two additional views of the same structure; one of which is similar in direction to the above, the other being photographed from Brooklyn.
About 1880
Gift of George T. Bagoe
No. 86 Madison Avenue.
No Reproductions
1299 B2 NEG. #4352

1299-B3
SLIDE AVAIL. # 196

730673f.title: Bridges - Brooklyn Bridge - [View of the sightseeing public walking the length of Brooklyn Bridge during its construction.]
730673f.text:
Brooklyn Bridge: An early view, taken in 1884.

1884
Neg # 2218
# 2218 A (2nd copy)

730671f-a.title: Bridges - Brooklyn Bridge - [View of the sightseeing public walking the length of Brooklyn Bridge during its construction.]
730671f-a.text:
(1)
Throngs of sight-seeing public visited the Brooklyn Bridge, to walk its length during its construction, and especially after its completion. The then marvel of engineering, was continually thronged with large crowds, as the view shows.
About 1884.
Eugene L. Armbruster, Collection.
(2)
The same; a later positive copy.
About 1884.
Eugene L. Armbruster, Collection.

Slide Avail. #194

730672f.title: Bridges - Brooklyn Bridge - [View of the sightseeing public walking the length of Brooklyn Bridge during its construction.]
730672f.text:
(3)
The same; a later negative copy.
About 1884.
Eugene L. Armbruster, Collection.

730678f-a.title: Bridges - Brooklyn Bridge - [Manhattan end of the bridge.]
730678f-a.text:
Brooklyn Bridge: A view of the Manhattan end, with its train shed.  Note the cables used for the train propulsion on the bridge incline.  Prominently shown, is the dome of the Pulitzer (World) Building, with the spire of the Tribune Building southward.

About 1890.

Brown Brothers.

Neg.# 2998

730676f-a.title: Bridges - Brooklyn Bridge - [East River - Manhattan.]
730676f-a.text:
Brooklyn Bridge, viewed southwestward from Brooklyn and showing same spanning the East River to Manhattan. Underneath the bedway, in the center, is the financial district with the spire of Trinity Church predominating. Outstanding at the right is the distinctive
Tribune Building.

About 1890
Mildenburg, photo
P. L. Sperr Collection

Neg # 4812

730677f-a.title: Bridges - Brooklyn Bridge - [View of the Swamp, an area populated by leather tanners.]
730677f-a.text:
Brooklyn Bridge, viewed northeastward from Manhattan and showing this engineering triumph spanning the East River to Brooklyn. In the foreground is the locality, better known as "The Swamp," an area populated by leather tanners.

About 1890
Mildenburg, photo
P. L. Sperr Collection

730679f-a.title: Bridges - Brooklyn Bridge - [Manhattan - East River - Brooklyn.]
730679f-a.text:
(1)
Brooklyn Bridge, as seen from the Manhattan side, looking east to Brooklyn.
About 1890.

(2)
Atop the Brooklyn Bridge, looking west along the pedestrian walk.

About 1890.
Gubelman

Neg # 4401

730679f-b.title: Bridges - Brooklyn Bridge - [Manhattan - East River - Brooklyn.]
730679f-b.text:
(1)

(2)

730681f.title: Bridges - Brooklyn Bridge - [Manhattan - East River - Brooklyn.]
730681f.text:
Brooklyn Bridge: A general view southward from same. Downtown Manhattan is on the right; Bedloes Island and its Statue of Liberty in the center and Governors Island (with its rotund "Castle William") to the left. In the foreground is a ferry boat preparing to dock at the ferry house at the foot of Fulton Street, Brooklyn.

1894
J. S. Johnston, photo
Copyright 1894
Ewing Galloway

Neg # 4611

730682f.title: Bridges - Brooklyn Bridge.
730682f.text:
53-63 Park Row, (Pulitzer or World Building), at the N. E. corner of Frankfort Street, showing a general view eastward of the Brooklyn Bridge, environs, the East River and the Brooklyn shore. The foreground area is the industrial section popularily known as the "Swamp." Dominant there is the 10-story Healy Building and the Shot Tower. The former is at Gold and Ferry Streets, while the latter is at Cliff and Beekman Streets. Thru the left midground runs Cherry Street, a one time fashionable thoroughfare that parallels the water front.

1894
J. S. Johnston photo
Copyright 1894
Ewing Galloway

730680f-a.title: Bridges - Brooklyn Bridge - [Manhattan - East River - Brooklyn.]
730680f-a.text:
Brooklyn Bridge as viewed northeastward from Manhattan and showing same spanning the East River to Brooklyn.

About 1893
J.S. Johnston, photo
Gift of Urbrock Collection

730695f-a.text:
Brooklyn Bridge, and the downtown Manhattan skyline, as seen from the Brooklyn side and viewing southwestward on the East River, Prominently shown, from left to right are, the Woolworth, Singer, Equitable, and the Bankers Trust Co. Buildings.

Brooklyn Bridge which spans the East River between Manhattan and Brooklyn. Manhattan Bridge above at left of picture.

About 1920.

Rotograph Co.

730699f-a.text:
The Brooklyn and Manhattan Bridges, as seen from the Manhattan side of the East River, and viewing eastward to Brooklyn. Note the painters giving the Brooklyn Bridge its annual protecting coat.
About 1925.
Ewing Galloway.

730704f-a.text:
Brooklyn Bridge: The financial district of lower Manhattan as viewed in a southwestward direction from Brooklyn and under the Brooklyn Bridge. The prominent building shown is the 70-storied structure of the Bank of Manhattan Company.

730717f-a.title: Bridges - Brooklyn Bridge.
730717f-a.text:
(1).  Brooklyn Bridge (suspension); beginning at Centre Street and Park Row, facing City Hall Park, in Manhattan, and terminating in Brooklyn at Fulton and Sands Streets. Actual work was begun in January, 1870 and it was completed in May, 1884, having been opened in the previous year. Its overall length is 1 1/4 miles, width 85 feet, with a central span across the East River, 1595 feet long and 135 feet above high water mark. John A. Roebling, who drew up the specifications and began construction was succeeded upon his death by his son, Washington A. Roebling. Being the first bridge to connect Manhattan and Brooklyn, it acquired a colorful history and world-wide fame as a wonder of modern engineering and human endeavor. (see: Moses King, Handbook of New York City (1892).)

June 15, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.

(2). Same
June 15, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.

(3). Same
June 15, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.

Actual work was begun in January, 1870 and it was completed in May, 1884, having been opened in the previous year. Its overall length is 1 1/4 miles, width 85 feet, with a central span across the East River, 1595 feet long and 135 feet above high water mark. John A. Roebling, who drew up the specifications and began construction was succeeded upon his death by his son, Washington A. Roebling. Being the first bridge to connect Manhattan and Brooklyn, it acquired a colorful history and world-wide fame as a wonder of modern engineering and human endeavor. 730731f-a.title: Bridges - Brooklyn Bridge - Manhattan approach.
730731f-a.text:
The Brooklyn Bridge and it's Manhattan approach as viewed eastward from the Municipal Building. This crosses the East River to the Brooklyn locale between the Columbia Heights area (right) and Flatbush Avenue Extension (left, approach to the Manhattan Bridge). The foreground zone has at times been known as the "Swamp" and "Cherry Hill".

April 1940
George D. Chinn

The two small snapshots made in 1898, the gift of Mrs. A. Gould, have no restrictions.

730701f-b.title: Bridges - Brooklyn Bridge - [Manhattan Bridge - Williamsburg Bridge - East River.]
730701f-b.text:
(1)
Brooklyn Bridge; followed by Manhattan Bridge; as seen from docks of lower east side.

June 12, 1925.
P. L. Sperr.

(2)
Another view of the two bridges. In the distant background is also
visible the Williamsburg Bridge.

October 8, 1934.
P. L. Sperr.
(No. 2 not a dry mount item).

730702f-b.title: Bridges - Brooklyn Bridge - [views showing lower Manhattan].
730702f-b.text:
(1)
Brooklyn Bridge: A view eastward showing the Manhattan skyline.
Shown from left to right are, the Woolworth Building; the Tribune Building spire; the World Building dome and the Municipal Building.

Summer 1925.
P. L. Sperr.
(Not a dry mount item).

(2)
A northward perspective and showing in addition the skeleton of
the Federal Courts Building.
January 8, 1934.

P. L. Sperr.
(Not a dry mount item).
Neg # 1651

(3)
Similar to No. 1, at a later date and showing the changed skyline.

May 24, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.
(Not a dry mount item).

730706f.title: Bridges - Brooklyn Bridge - [Hearst Enterprises; Pulitzer Building; Woolworth Building.]
730706f.text:
(1)
Sea going schooner passing underneath the Brooklyn Bridge. The
Hearst Enterprises Building may also be seen.

June 4, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.

(2)
The same, from a different angle, showing the Manhattan end of
the Brooklyn Bridge.

June 4, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.

(3)
The same, three years later, from another angle.

June 4, 1932.
P. L. Sperr.

730707f-a.title: Bridges - Brooklyn Bridge - [view from Wall and Pearle Streets].
730707f-a.text:
(1)
Brooklyn Bridge and Manhattan Bridge, in their order, as seen from lower east end of Manhattan, looking north up the East River.

June 26, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.

(2)
The same, from a further distance; view is from building at Wall
and Pearl Streets.

October 1, 1930.
P. L. Sperr.

July 8, 1930.
P. L. Sperr.

(2) The same, taken from the twenty-second floor of the Municipal Building.

June 11, 1931.
P. L. Sperr.

730710f-a.title: Bridges - Brooklyn Bridge - [Manhattan Bridge.]
730710f-a.text:
1- Brooklyn Bridge, looking southeast towards Brooklyn; from atop
the Manhattan Bridge, at Canal Street.

2- Brooklyn Bridge approach from Brooklyn. Manhattan Bridge and
uptown Manhattan are also seen in this view.

3- Brooklyn Bridge's majestic suspension has been adjudged the engineering masterpiece of its time. Manhattan Bridge is also seen.

P. L. Sperr
View 1: May 9, 1930
View 2: June 15, 1933
View 3: July 9, 1933

September 23, 1931.

730712f-a.title: Bridges - Brooklyn Bridge.
730712f-a.text:
(1)
Dominating the East River; and connecting two great sister boroughs; the Brooklyn Bridge has truly earned its world wide fame.

May 3, 1932.
P. L. Sperr.

(2)
Brooklyn Bridge, one year later

June 22, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.

730713f-b.title: Bridges - Brooklyn Bridge - [Lower Manhattan skyline.]
730713f-b.text:
Lower Manhattan skyline, is seen from the Brooklyn Bridge, looking
southwest.

June 5, 1932.
P. L. Sperr.

View 2,
The Brooklyn Bridge view northward to show beneath same Knickerbocker Village. The White structure to the right front of the same is the Hearst Publications Building, on South Street. To the extreme right appears a portion the Manhattan Bridge.

September l6, 1935.

View 3,
Brooklyn Bridge; over the roof tops of lower East side of Manhattan, looking north east from Fulton and Gold Streets.

August 1, 1930.

730721f.title: Bridges - Brooklyn Bridge - [Pedestrian walk - Federal Courts Building; Municipal Building; Woolworth Building.]
730721f.text:
(1) Brooklyn Bridge  The pedestrian walk atop the Bridge. The view is westward towards Manhattan. Note the Woolworth Building on the left.

About 1936.
Gift of Dr. Michael Wishengrad A.R.P.S.

(2) A view in the same direction, slightly northward, showing the Municipal Building and the Federal Courts Building; the latter under construction.

June 24, 1935.
P. L. Sperr.
(views 1 A 2 not dry mount items).

(3) Similar to No. 2 and showing the Federal Court Building completed.

May 24, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.
(Not a dry mount item).

730723f-b.title: Bridges - Brooklyn Bridge - [Pedestrian walk - Municipal Building.]
730723f-b.text:
Brooklyn Bridge: A view of the pedestrian walk atop the Bridge, looking westward to Manhattan from mid-stream. Note the tower of the Municipal Building on the right. View No. 1 is an enlargement made by the photographer; No. 2 being a copy of the original by the N. Y. P. L.

About 1936.
Gift of Dr. Michael Wishengrad A. R. P. S.
not a dry mount
1301/B6 Neg. # 5067
1301/B7 Neg. # 4400

730726f-b.text:
Brooklyn and Manhattan Bridges: View 1 shows the Brooklyn towers of the Brooklyn and Manhattan Bridges, viewed northeastward.

View 2 is south on the East River and shows the Manhattan and Brooklyn Bridges and the Lower Manhattan skyline.

P. L. Sperr
View 1 July 10, 1937
View 2: September 16, 1935

730743f-a.title: Bridges - Brooklyn Bridge - [View of the bridge over East River, as it stretches from Brooklyn to Manhattan.]
730743f-a.text:
FROM BROOKLYN TO NEW YORK -- TODAY AND YESTERDAY
Two views of the world famous Brooklyn Bridge as it stretches from Brooklyn to Manhattan. Compare the two, one made today and the other "many, many years ago", and note the drastic changes that have taken place.

Photo by Underwood and Underwood  N.D.

730744f-a.title: Bridges - Brooklyn Bridge - [View of the bridge over East River, as it stretches from Brooklyn to Manhattan.]
730744f-a.text:
FROM BROOKLYN TO NEW YORK--TODAY AND YESTERDAY
Two views of the world famous Brooklyn Bridge as it stretches from Brooklyn toward Manhattan. Compare the two, one made today and the other "many, many years ago", and note the drastic changes that have taken place.

See preceding photo

A STUDY IN STEEL
An unusual study of the Brooklyn Bridge as it stretches from Brooklyn, N.Y., to Manhattan, across the East River. In the distance may be seen New York's world-famous skyline.

Photographs by Underwood and Underwood.
N.D.
